newsitem.title: UK: Japanese stocks in London barely changed, quiet.
newsitem.headline: Japanese stocks in London barely changed, quiet.

text.p: Japanese shares in London were little changed but with a slightly easier bias on Tuesday after profit-taking hit some leading stocks.
London's Nikkei/Ise 50 index was up just 0.01 points at 1,438.38 by 1330 GMT.

"Since the election, foreign investors have been lightening their exposure to Japan," said one trader. "Some of the household names that have led the market up recently are now leading the market back down."
Traders said Fujitsu was one of the stocks hit by profit-taking.
The shares were trading at 1,024 yen in London after a Tokyo close of 1,030.
Shares in Honda Motor were down 10 yen from the close in Japan, trading at 2,690 yen by 1330 GMT.
Elsewhere, traders said news that Nichiei Finance had applied for liquidation had hit sentiment surrounding bank and finance stocks.
"Some of the banks are looking shaky after the news highlighted the fact that they still have large amounts of bad loans on their books," one said.
Sakura Bank slipped to 1,085 yen in London, from 1,100 in Tokyo and Fuji Bank was trading at 2,102.5 yen after finishing at 2,110 in Japan.
But dealers said Tokyo stocks, which have been feeble since the election could soon bottom out.
"I expect another weak day in Tokyo but as we approach 21,000 the market is slowing down on the downside, so we could see some fairly good support around this level," a dealer said.
The Nikkei 225 closed at 21,123.68 on Tuesday having lost 179.27 points, or 0.84 percent.
